A few years ago, my friend Prisha traveled across South Asia for her research project on the impact of globalization on the region. During her travels, she came across many small businesses in India, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Bhutan that were struggling to survive. Many of them lacked access to funds, markets, and technology.
Fast forward to today, the European Union (EU) has been increasingly engaging with these countries to promote economic growth, reduce poverty, and improve governance in the region. The EU's engagement with South Asia is driven by its interest in expanding trade and investment opportunities, strengthening regional cooperation, and promoting human rights, democracy, and sustainable development.
The EU's growing engagement with South Asia can have several potential benefits for the region. Here are some notable examples:
The EU is one of the largest trading powers in the world, accounting for over 15% of global trade. By engaging with South Asia, the EU seeks to increase its trade and investment in the region, especially in sectors such as textiles, agriculture, and services. This can help boost the local economies, create jobs, and improve people's standard of living.
The EU is keen on promoting regional integration and connectivity in South Asia, which can help improve trade and commerce within the region. The EU has been supporting various infrastructure projects in the region, such as the development of seaports, highways, and railways. This can help improve transport links between South Asian countries and facilitate regional trade and cooperation.

Once upon a time, there was a small country that relied heavily on exports to a neighboring giant. The giant decided to flex its economic muscles and began putting pressure on the small country to comply with its demands. In response, the small country rallied its allies and tried to fight back, but it only ended up hurting itself more.
This story is not a fairytale, but a real-life situation that many countries are facing today. China's economic coercion on its trading partners is a controversial and complex issue, but the West's response to it has been misguided and misleading.
The West's approach to dealing with China's economic coercion is often based on retaliation and protectionism. The US, for example, has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, restricted Chinese investment in certain industries, and blacklisted Chinese companies. Similarly, the UK, Australia, and Canada have taken measures to limit Chinese investment, screen Chinese acquisitions, and ban Huawei from their 5G networks.
While these actions may seem like a tough stance against China, they are misguided for several reasons. First, they are unlikely to change China's behavior because China is not easily intimidated or coerced. Second, they harm the West's own interests by disrupting supply chains, raising consumer prices, and reducing market access. Third, they push China closer to other countries like Russia and Iran, which undermines the West's efforts to isolate those countries.
The negative impact of the West's fight against China's economic coercion can be seen in various sectors and regions.
https://akash.mittal.blog/geopolitics/2023/6/2/The-Misguided-Fight-Against-China-s-Economic-Coercion.html
#trending #China #EconomicCoercion #West #Protectionism #Engagement #Diversification #RulesBasedCooperation

It was a glorious day for all Indian hockey fans as India beat Pakistan to win the Junior Asia Cup Hockey. It was a nail-biting match that kept the audience glued to their seats until the very end. The Indian team put up a remarkable performance to beat their arch-rivals by a score of 3-1.
The game started with a lot of aggression from both teams. Pakistan was the first one to score a goal and took an early lead. However, India quickly regained their momentum and scored two back-to-back goals to take the lead. The last goal was scored by India in the final moments of the game, leaving Pakistan with no time to recover.
The Indian team had trained hard for months, and their hard work paid off in the end. They had set a goal to win the tournament and worked tirelessly towards achieving it. Their resilience, determination, and teamwork made them unbeatable. The players had the right mindset and attitude that helped them overcome the challenges they faced throughout the tournament. Their victory was well-deserved, and they certainly made the country proud.
This win is a testament to the rise of Indian hockey and its bright future. The junior players displayed exceptional skills and talent, proving that the future of Indian hockey is in good hands. This win will certainly inspire young players to take up the sport and work towards achieving their dreams.
This victory was a moment of joy for all Indians, and it will be remembered for a long time. The Indian junior team has set a new benchmark with their performance, and it's a significant moment in the history of Indian sports. Congratulations to the Indian team on their achievement!

Once upon a time, in a small village in India, a couple named Ram and Sita celebrated the birth of their third child, Raj. As per their tradition, they distributed sweets and invited their friends and family to celebrate. However, one of their neighbors, who had only one child, looked at them with envy and said, "You people are responsible for the population explosion in our country."
This incident illustrates how population growth has become a contentious issue in India and China. With a population of 1.4 billion, China is the world's most populous country while India with a population of 1.3 billion is not far behind. Both countries are experiencing demographic changes that will impact not only their own future but also the future of the world. However, population growth is not a competition between China and India, and it is important to understand the unique challenges they face.
In the past, both China and India had high fertility rates, which resulted in a population explosion. However, with advancements in healthcare and education, fertility rates have decreased. China implemented the one-child policy in 1979 to control population growth, which resulted in a decrease in the fertility rate from 5.9 in 1970 to 1.6 in 2018. In India, the fertility rate decreased from 5.9 in 1960 to 2.2 in 2018.
As a result, the demographic structure of both countries is changing. China's population is aging rapidly, with the proportion of elderly people increasing. On the other hand, India has a young population, with the majority of the population being under 35 years of age. These changes will impact social security, healthcare, and economy of both countries in different ways.
Both China and India face unique challenges due to their demographic changes. In China, the aging population will strain the healthcare system and social security. The younger generations will have to support an increasing number of elderly retirees, which will impact their economic growth. On the other hand, India has a youth bulge which can result in unemployment and poverty if the government is unable to create enough jobs for them. There is also a need to invest in education and healthcare to ensure that the younger generation is skilled and healthy enough to contribute to the economy.
https://akash.mittal.blog/geopolitics/2023/6/2/Population-Change-Not-a-Game-Between-China-and-India-ECNS-cn.html
#trending #PopulationChange #China #India #DemographicChanges #HumanCapital

As tensions continue to rise between India and China over the Eastern Ladakh region, top military and diplomatic officials from both sides have met in New Delhi for talks aimed at easing the tensions. The two nations have been locked in a bitter dispute for the past year, with both sides accusing the other of aggressive military posturing and territorial incursions. The talks, which took place on Friday, were described as "constructive" by both sides, but experts say that a lasting resolution to the conflict remains a distant prospect.
It's difficult to pinpoint one specific incident that has led to the current situation in Eastern Ladakh. However, tensions have been simmering between India and China in this region for many years. Both nations claim ownership of large swathes of land in this region, which is located in the Himalayan mountains. The dispute stretches back more than six decades, with both countries engaging in several skirmishes over the years.
The Eastern Ladakh region is home to several strategically important regions, including the Aksai Chin plateau, which is a vital road link for China. India, on the other hand, has been expanding its infrastructure in the region, building roads and airstrips to increase its military presence. In the past year, China has stepped up its military presence in the region, with troops and armored vehicles being deployed to disputed areas. Both sides have accused the other of violating their territorial boundaries.
Eastern Ladakh Row: Can India and China Find a Way Out?
One case study that illustrates the challenges of the Eastern Ladakh conflict is the Galwan Valley clash of 2020, in which 20 Indian soldiers were killed and several others injured. The incident, which marked the first deadly clash between the two nations in decades, highlighted the dangers of escalating tensions in the region. It also showed how quickly a small skirmish between troops can spiral out of control and lead to a much larger conflict. It is crucial that both sides continue to engage in diplomatic talks to prevent the situation from worsening further.

Cricket is not just a game but a religion in India and Pakistan, and the rivalry between the two teams is legendary. But the latest news has shocked the cricket fans as the Asia Cup 2023 could be held without Pakistan Cricket Team.
The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) has reportedly informed its Asian counterparts that it won't be able to host the event if Pakistan's team participates in it. The Pakistan Cricket Board (PCB) has reacted strongly to the news, stating that it is a violation of the International Cricket Council's (ICC) rules and regulations.
Let's dive deeper into the issue and try to understand why the Asia Cup 2023 may be held without the Pakistani team, and what are the potential consequences of this decision.
The history of India-Pakistan cricket matches goes back to 1952, and since then, the two teams have faced each other in more than 200 matches across all formats of the game. Here are some quantifiable examples of the impact of India-Pakistan cricket matches on the world:
The BCCI's decision to not host the Asia Cup with Pakistan's participation has roots in the history of India-Pakistan relations. The two countries have a long history of conflicts and disputes, and cricket has often been used as a tool for political propaganda by both sides.

The oil and gas industry has always been one of the most interesting industries to observe. It is dynamic, competitive and has high stakes. With the world entering the post-Covid era, the oil and gas industry is taking center stage once again. Recently, India and China, which are two of the biggest oil consuming countries in the world, have set a new record by importing Russian crude oil.

According to the data from oil analytics company Kpler, India imported his second-highest monthly amount of crude oil from Russia, totalling 1.2 million barrels per day (bpd) and China imported 7.26 million tonnes of Russian crude oil in May, which equates to about 1.75 million bpd. It is important to mention that, despite the geopolitical tensions and border disputes between the two countries, India and China are still importing crude oil from Russia.

It was a cold winter night in eastern Ukraine, and a group of Ukrainian soldiers were preparing to launch a counter-offensive against Russian-backed separatists. As they made their way across the barren landscape towards the enemy's positions, they came across a network of trenches that snaked their way across the frozen earth.
The Ukrainian soldiers quickly realized that these trenches posed a major challenge to their counter-offensive. Not only did they provide the enemy with excellent cover and concealment, but they also made it difficult for the Ukrainian soldiers to maneuver and attack.
Trenches are a common feature of warfare, dating back to ancient times. They're often used to provide protection and cover for soldiers, allowing them to avoid enemy fire and provide a strong defensive position. However, they also have some major drawbacks.
These are the challenges that Ukrainian soldiers faced when they encountered the Russian trenches. But it wasn't just the trenches themselves that posed a problem – it was the way they were organized and structured that made them particularly challenging.

It was a crisp Autumn morning in 2019 when Narendra Modi made a historic decision that would have a major impact on the complex geopolitical relationship between Pakistan and China.
India had long been concerned about the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), a multi-billion dollar infrastructure project that aims to connect the western Chinese region of Xinjiang with the Arabian Sea port of Gwadar in Pakistan via a network of railways, highways, and pipelines. India saw this project as a violation of its sovereignty, as it passes through the disputed region of Kashmir.
Modi's decision was to abrogate Article 370 of the Indian constitution, which granted special status to Jammu and Kashmir, the Indian-administered region that Pakistan claims as its own. This move sent shockwaves across the region and beyond, as it effectively nullified the CPEC project and put a strain on the Pakistan-China relationship.
The impact of Modi's decision can be measured in several ways:
"Modi's decision has had far-reaching consequences that go beyond the India-Pakistan conflict. It has impacted the entire region and could potentially reshape the global balance of power."

It was the mid-2000s, and the BRICS bloc of developing countries—Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa—had begun to stir. A former U.S. ambassador was in China discussing the challenges the United States faced in engaging the rising economic power. She cited the U.S. Conference Board's Global Consumer Confidence Index, which compared the confidence of consumers in different countries. At the time, China's confidence was 20 points higher than that of the United States. The ambassador warned that, with its economic and political rise, not only would China's confidence continue to rise, but leaders in Beijing would be in a stronger position to challenge the United States on a global scale.
Fast-forward to today, and a new report from the World Economic Forum suggests that the U.S.-led international order that helped secure relative peace and prosperity for 70 years is in decline. The report says that, as the U.S. retreats from global leadership, countries like China, Russia, and their allies within BRICS are filling the space at an alarming rate.
Examples of this trend abound across various fields. In the realm of international trade, China is fast becoming the dominant player. It now accounts for 14 percent of world trade, compared to just 5 percent in 2000. Last year, China accounted for 80 percent of all corporate debt sold outside of the United States. In the technology race, Chinese companies like Huawei, TikTok, and WeChat are leading the way. In April 2020, Huawei became the world's top smartphone seller, bumping Samsung out of the top spot it had held for almost a decade. And in the diplomatic arena, Russia and China are increasingly forming a united front against the United States, with the two countries partnering on issues like Iran, North Korea, and Venezuela.
The world is changing fast, and the United States is losing ground to China, Russia, and their BRICS allies. Why We Must Pay Attention to the Growing BRICS Bloc, Before It's Too Late?
As someone who has lived and worked in both the United States and China, I have seen firsthand the differences in approach to global engagement. In China, there is a clear sense of national pride and a feeling of momentum that comes from being part of a rising power. There is also a strong emphasis on education and innovation, with a focus on developing world-leading technologies and industries.

Once upon a time, there was a small country named Lewiston with amazing economic growth. Its currency was so strong that it surpassed the American dollar. People started to flock to Lewiston to experience its thriving economy, but all of a sudden, the economy collapsed. The people were shocked and they could not comprehend what went wrong. In the end, it turned out that Lewiston's economy was dependent on only one industry, which caused the economy to crumble. This is an example of the importance of diversifying the economy and providing stability for the people.
Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, the BRICS nations, have been working together to create stability in their economies. With the United States being the world's largest economy, they have been trying to counteract its power. With this goal in mind, the BRICS nations are considering the expansion of their shared currency, which is known as the BRICSCOIN.
A shared currency provides numerous economic benefits. It allows for easier and more direct trading, reduces transaction fees, and encourages greater economic cooperation among the participating nations. Countries using the same currency can also provide each other with financial assistance in times of economic crisis, which makes them more self-sufficient and less dependent on international organizations such as the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. With shared currency, the BRICSCOIN, the economies of these nations will be more stable.
A shared currency enables the economies of each nation to complement each other. Brazil is a major exporter of agricultural products; Russia is a major exporter of oil; India is a major exporter of textiles; China is a major exporter of electronics; and South Africa exports a variety of products. By sharing a currency, the nations can help each other by buying and selling goods with ease.
Currently, the BRICSCOIN is only used for trade between the participating nations. However, the BRICS are considering expanding its range to include other countries, and the possibility of becoming a global currency. If the BRICS succeed in expanding the BRICSCOIN, the balance of power in the world could shift, as it would provide another currency option for countries to use besides the American dollar.
https://akash.mittal.blog/geopolitics/2023/6/2/Brics-Strive-to-Counter-US-with-Expansion-of-Shared-Currency.html
#trending #BRICSCOIN #BRICS #expansionofsharedcurrency #economicgrowth

Austin, the United States' defense secretary, expressed his disappointment in Singapore on Friday, as he revealed that he was unable to secure a meeting with his Chinese counterpart. The unfruitful visit by the defense secretary is a huge setback to the relationship between the United States and China.
The strained relationship between the two superpowers may have caused Chinese officials to decline a meeting with Austin during his visit. The United States and China have been at loggerheads over a range of issues from the COVID-19 pandemic, trade war, human rights, and Taiwan. Austin had earlier voiced his concerns about China's military expansion and said that the US is ready to counter threats that it sees from China.
This was Austin's first visit to Asia since he took over from his predecessor, Mark Esper, earlier this year. The Secretary of Defense had been hoping to meet with his Chinese counterpart to dialogue about reducing tensions. Unfortunately, he was not able to secure the meeting, although Austin says that he remains open to "constructive, stable, and professional" dialogue.
The breakdown of communication between the two superpowers is a worrying sign of the deteriorating relationship. Although the US government says that it is not looking for conflict with China, the absence of meaningful dialogue could lead to more tensions and escalation of conflict.
The decision by Beijing not to meet with Austin underscores the challenges faced by the Biden administration in trying to find common ground with China. President Biden has made it clear that he wants to build a stable and predictable relationship with China, but this has been a difficult task given the complexities of the relationship between the two countries.

As a child, I remember listening to stories from my grandfather about the relations between two of the most populous countries, China and India. Being a history buff, he would often narrate tales of the Silk Route and how it brought these two countries closer to each other. However, as I grew up, I realized that the relations between China and India are not as simple as they seem. Despite the cultural similarities and business opportunities, the relationship between the two neighbouring countries have always been strained and challenged with border disputes and economic competition.
China and India, with a combined population of 2.8 billion people, are often seen as the powerhouses of Asia, who hold a significant influence on the global economy and politics. Both countries have emerged as strong economies, and over the past few years, have established themselves as two of the fastest-growing economies in the world. However, their economic progress has been overshadowed by their border disputes and military clashes, which have left a significant impact on the region's geopolitical environment.

by Computerworld
China has become a major player in the tech industry in recent years, with companies like Huawei, ZTE, and TikTok gaining prominence and market share. However, concerns have been raised about the close ties between Chinese tech firms and the Chinese government, as well as accusations of intellectual property theft and espionage.
The US government has been increasingly wary of China's influence on the global tech market, and has taken steps to limit Chinese tech firms' access to US technology and markets. Now, new laws are being proposed to ban US investors from buying shares in Chinese tech firms, citing national security concerns and the need to protect American intellectual property.
The proposed ban would have a significant impact on both Chinese tech firms and US investors. Chinese tech firms could lose access to vital sources of funding, limiting their ability to expand and innovate. US investors, on the other hand, would be forced to divest from existing holdings in Chinese tech firms, potentially causing a disruption in the market.
However, proponents of the ban argue that it is necessary to protect US interests and prevent Chinese tech firms from gaining too much power and influence. They point to examples like Huawei, which has been accused of cyber-espionage and has been the subject of multiple US sanctions, as evidence of the risks posed by Chinese tech firms.

Once upon a time, a young Pakistani boy named Ali dreamed of making it big. With his intelligence and hard work, he managed to graduate from a prestigious university in Islamabad and landed a well-paying job. But despite his efforts, he found it hard to make ends meet. Inflation was soaring, and the Pakistani rupee was losing value against the US dollar. He worried about his future and the future of his country.
Unfortunately, Ali's story is not unique. Pakistan has been facing economic challenges for years. Inflation, debt, and a widening current account deficit have all contributed to the country's economic woes. The COVID-19 pandemic has only made things worse, as Pakistan's economy shrank by 0.4% in the fiscal year 2019-2020.
So what's the solution? Pakistan is once again turning to the International Monetary Fund (IMF) for help. The country has already received multiple loans from the IMF over the years, but this time, it's seeking a loan of $6 billion to stabilize its economy and restore growth.
The pandemic has had a devastating impact on Pakistan's economy. The country's textile and manufacturing industries, which account for a significant portion of its exports, have been hit hard. With global demand plummeting, Pakistani exporters have struggled to find buyers for their products.
The tourism industry, which was growing rapidly in recent years, has also been badly affected. The closure of borders and travel restrictions have resulted in a sharp decline in tourist arrivals, hurting businesses and leaving millions unemployed.

It all started with a border dispute in the western Himalayas – an area known as the Galwan Valley – between India and China in June 2020. The dispute, which resulted in the loss of lives on both sides, escalated the tensions between the two world powers.
As the diplomatic relations between India and China soured, mutual accusations of espionage and media manipulation added fuel to the fire. Following reciprocal expulsions, China says its reporters in India are about to drop to zero. This story is all about the unfolding events that led to this outcome.
In September 2020, two Chinese journalists working for Xinhua news agency were expelled from India allegedly for carrying out activities beyond their journalistic brief.
In March 2021, India expelled another three Chinese journalists, also accusing them of indulging in activities beyond their journalistic brief. Following the expulsions, China says that its reporters in India are about to drop to zero.
These expulsions have effectively reduced the media presence of both countries in the other. The two neighbors are now left with a handful of correspondents who are faced with increasing challenges not only in reporting from the field but also in accessing information from their sources.

Recently, the Prime Minister of Pakistan, Imran Khan, has been making headlines with his controversial statements about the Afghan Taliban and its relation with India. In a recent interview, Khan defended the Taliban and criticized India for its alleged interference in Afghan affairs. His comments have raised eyebrows around the world, with many wondering what his true intentions are.
The Afghan Taliban has been in control of large parts of Afghanistan since US troops began their withdrawal from the country earlier this year. The group has been widely criticized for its human rights abuses and its oppressive policies towards women. However, Imran Khan has defended the Taliban, calling them "normal citizens" who are "sharing power" in Afghanistan.
Khan's comments have been seen by many as an attempt to curry favor with the Taliban, which is widely believed to have ties to Pakistan's military and intelligence agencies. However, Khan has denied any such links and has repeatedly denied accusations that Pakistan is supporting the Taliban's insurgency in Afghanistan.
Despite Khan's denials, there is evidence to suggest that Pakistan has been supporting the Taliban in some way. According to a report by the US Defense Intelligence Agency, Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency has been providing "logistical support and sanctuary" to the Taliban for years.
In addition, there have been numerous reports of Taliban fighters receiving medical treatment in Pakistan and of Pakistan's intelligence agencies providing the group with weapons and training. Although Khan has denied these allegations, many are skeptical of his claims.

It was a beautiful summer morning in the Indian Himalayas, and the sun had just risen over the majestic snow-capped peaks. The trees were lush green, the air was fresh and crisp, and the birds were chirping. Suddenly, a loud explosion ripped through the valley, shaking the ground and shattering the tranquility. A plume of smoke rose up from a military outpost on the ridge, which was under attack by Chinese troops.
This is not a scene from a Hollywood movie or a work of fiction. It is a real-life scenario that could happen any day now, as China's President Xi Jinping is plotting a war against India over the Himalayas.
China and India have been engaged in a long-standing military standoff over the Himalayan border region of Ladakh, which both countries claim as their own. This conflict dates back to the 1960s but has escalated in recent years.
China has been taking a more aggressive stance in this region, building military outposts, and deploying troops, tanks, and missiles to the area. India, on the other hand, has responded by beefing up its own military presence and infrastructure, such as roads and bridges, to improve its connectivity to the region.
The situation came to a head in June 2020, when Chinese troops attacked Indian soldiers in the Galwan Valley, resulting in the deaths of 20 Indian soldiers and an unknown number of Chinese soldiers. This was the first time in over 40 years that there had been a loss of life on the border.

Once upon a time, there were two great nations, the United States and China. Both had different backgrounds, cultures, and systems of government, but they also shared similarities in their economy, global influence, and military power. They had a history of working together for the greater good, but recent developments in their relationship have led to deepening conflicts and tensions.
The ongoing trade war between the U.S and China has been a major source of discord between the two nations. Since 2018, when the U.S imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, the economic relationship has become increasingly strained. China, in turn, responded by imposing its own tariffs on American products. The result has been a significant impact on both countries' economies, with businesses on both sides being heavily affected.
Another area of contention between the U.S and China is human rights. The Chinese government has been criticized for its treatment of ethnic minorities in its western region of Xinjiang and for its crackdown on pro-democracy activists in Hong Kong. This has led to further calls for the U.S to take a stronger stance in promoting democratic values and human rights.
Despite these issues, there are also areas where the U.S and China have cooperated, such as climate change, nuclear disarmament, and global health issues. However, as the world continues to face unprecedented challenges, the U.S and China must find ways to work together for the greater good.
The U.S and China have one of the world's largest trading relationships, with over $660 billion in goods and services exchanging between the two nations. However, due to the ongoing trade war, both countries' economies have been affected significantly. In 2019, China's GDP growth slowed down to 6.1%, the lowest in almost 30 years, while the U.S economy has experienced declines in exports and investment.

It was a typical hot summer day in the rural Chinese village of Dongzhen when farmer Li Jun received a visit from local government officials. They had come to inspect his crops as part of a nationwide effort to boost agricultural production and secure food supplies for the country's swelling population. But Li Jun had little to show for his hard work. The once-fertile land was now barren, stripped of its nutrients by years of overuse and neglect. Li Jun knew he was not alone in his plight. Across China, farmers were struggling to feed their families and make ends meet as the cost of inputs rose and yields declined.
The crisis facing China's agriculture sector is not new. For years, the government has been grappling with a host of challenges, from land degradation and water scarcity to rising labor costs and changing consumer preferences. But as the country's population approaches 1.4 billion, and as demand for high-quality, safe, and diversified food rises, the situation has become more urgent. China's leadership has made food security a top priority, but achieving it will require systemic changes and sustained investment.
The numbers tell the story of China's agriculture woes. According to a recent report by the Agricultural Bank of China, the country's grain output fell by 1.2% in 2020, the first decline in five years. Meanwhile, the average age of farmers in China is now over 50, and the number of agricultural workers has fallen by 30 million since 2000. This demographic shift is exacerbating the labor shortage and making it harder for farmers to adopt new technologies and practices.
At the same time, China's appetite for meat and dairy products is growing rapidly, fueled by rising incomes and a desire for a more Western-style diet. The country's meat consumption has increased tenfold in the past 40 years, making it the world's largest producer and consumer of pork. But this trend is not sustainable, both from an environmental and a health perspective. Meat production is a major source of greenhouse gas emissions and contributes to deforestation, while excessive consumption of animal products is a leading cause of chronic diseases such as obesity and heart disease.
The challenges facing China's agriculture sector are complex and multifaceted, but there are some key steps that can be taken to address them. These include:

It was a beautiful sunny day when the Indian Army received a report from one of its forward observation posts (OPs) near the Line of Actual Control (LAC) about the unusual movements of Chinese aircraft. The report was immediately forwarded to the higher authorities who were puzzled as to why the Chinese were moving their aircraft so close to the Indian border. As it turns out, the Chinese were setting up one of their airbases in the region, which had gone unnoticed until now.
This was just one of the many instances where China is silently scaling up its air power along the LAC. According to the latest satellite images that we have obtained, China has been building new airbases, expanding the existing ones, and deploying the latest fighter jets and transport planes in the region. The aim seems to be to gain a major strategic advantage over India, which has been caught off guard by the sudden Chinese aggression.
One of the most quantifiable examples of China's air power buildup is the expansion of the Hotan airbase near the LAC. As per the satellite images, China has deployed advanced Su-30 fighter jets and Y-20 transport planes at the airbase, which can fly at higher altitudes and travel longer distances than India's aging aircraft. This gives China an unfair advantage in the region as they can easily outmaneuver and outpace the Indian Air Force (IAF) in case of a conflict.
Another example of China's air power build-up is the construction of a new airbase in the Tibet Autonomous Region. This airbase is strategically located and can provide China enough cover to launch a surprise attack on India's military locations in case of a conflict. The satellite images show the presence of J-11 and J-16 fighter jets, both of which are superior to India's MiG-21 and Su-30MKI aircraft.
In addition to building new airbases and deploying advanced fighter jets and transport planes, China is also enhancing its infrastructure along the LAC. The latest satellite imagery shows new and upgraded runways, taxiways, and maintenance facilities at some of the existing airbases. This allows China to maintain a higher operational tempo and keep its aircraft ready for action at a moment's notice.
